summary: This is a sealed transcript of a conference before Chief District Judge Colleen McMahon regarding a grand jury subpoena (19 Misc. 149). The government attorney explains that the investigation into the subject (implicitly Jeffrey Epstein) was opened in late November/early December 2018, and that the U.S. Attorney's Office had contacted the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner, among other plaintiff attorneys, because they represented victims or witnesses. The court grants the government's request related to the subpoena.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Presiding judge over the grand jury subpoena conference. She questions the government attorney about contacts with the Boies Schiller firm prior to the subpoena's issuance.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Listed as the United States Attorney in the appearances. The government attorney speaking is likely from his office.

connections.description: Berman's office (represented by an AUSA) is appearing before Judge McMahon in a sealed grand jury subpoena proceeding.

events.title: Investigation Opened (Approx. Date)
events.description: The government attorney states the investigation into the subject (Epstein) was opened on either Friday, November 30, or Monday, December 3, 2018.

events.title: Sealed Grand Jury Subpoena Conference
events.description: Court conference before Judge McMahon regarding the government's application for a grand jury subpoena, likely related to documents held by the Boies Schiller firm.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The document is a sealed transcript of a court conference regarding a grand jury subpoena (19 Misc. 149) related to the Epstein investigation.
The government investigation into the subject (Epstein) was opened in late November or early December 2018 (Nov 30 or Dec 3).
The U.S. Attorney's Office contacted the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner early in the investigation because they represented victims or witnesses.
Boies Schiller indicated a protective order might govern some materials, leading to the government's subpoena application to the court.
Judge Colleen McMahon granted the government's request related to the subpoena.
